summary: Caitlin Southwick (MSc., PD) holds a Professional Doctorate and Masters of Science in Conservation and Restoration of Cultural Heritage from the University of Amsterdam and a Graduate Degree in Conservation Practice from Cardiff University. She has over eight years of training and experience in conservation field and has worked at some of the most high-profile institutions and sites around the world, including The Vatican Museums, The Uffizi Gallery, The Getty Conservation Institute and Rapa Nui. Her interest in sustainability derives from her personal passion for the environment and she believes strongly in the duality of preserving culture and the planet. In 2016, she founded Sustainability in Conservation, the leading international organization dedicated to environmentally conscious practices in art conservation. She served as a professional member of the American Institute for Conservation’s Sustainability Committee from 2017-2019 and is the Secretary of the Working Group on Sustainability for the International Council of Museums (2018-present) and the head of the Sustainability Platform for the International Institute of Conservation. She is on the Climate Steering Committee for Europeana and a trained Climate Reality Leader. She is the Founder and Executive Director of Ki Culture, an international organization dedicated to making sustainability sustainable through culture.

Developed my skills as a conservator and learned about working in a lab with teams of conservators specialising in different areas. Worked on high profile projects including frescos in the Palazzo Vecchio, a 16th century calcareous stone sculpture from the garden of the Piccolomini Centiale Villa in Siena and a gesso sarcophagus used by Pope Benedict XVI at the Meeting of Families in Milan.', 'title': 'Intern', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': None, 'name': 'Galleria degli Uffizi', 'logo': None, 'url': None, 'employees': {'start': None, 'end': None}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}, 'end': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Florence, Italy', 'date': {'start': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}, 'end': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}}, 'company': 'Galleria degli Uffizi', 'description': 'Worked with accredited stone conservator Miriam Ricci and curator Antonio Paolucci on the restoration of a 2nd century AD Roman marble statue Venere con Eros that is currently on display in the gallery of the Uffizi. Work included cleaning using distilled water, ethanol alcohol and white spirit applied with cotton swab, removal of previous restorations (stucco and overpainting) using scalpels and distilled water, integrations and infilling of missing areas with polyfilla and repainting using a puntini technique with watercolour.', 'title': 'Intern', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': None, 'name': 'Easter Island Restoration Project', 'logo': None, 'url': None, 'employees': {'start': None, 'end': None}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}, 'end': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Easter Island', 'date': {'start': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}, 'end': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}}, 'company': 'Easter Island Restoration Project', 'description': 'One of three students selected to go to Easter Island to conduct the first restoration of a Moai statue. The project’s aim was to restore of one of the Moai statues while teaching a group of local workers the process in order that they may continue the restoration of their cultural heritage. The main treatment was the removal of the lichen on the statues using a combination of solvent treatments (to kill the lichen, applied in spray form) and mechanical removal of the lichen. Our project was documented on film and was also featured in an article in National Geographic Italia.', 'title': 'Student Conservator', 'employment_type': None}]}]
